awd_titl_txt: Decoupled Ion-Conduction Mechanism of Protein-based Electrolytes: Simulation and Experimental Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
High performance and safe batteries are increasingly demanded in today's energy supply markets. Developing advanced solid electrolytes to replace liquid electrolytes is critical for fulfillment of higher energy density and safer batteries for automotive applications. Conventional solid polymer electrolytes are of great interest owing to their processing ease and cost-effectiveness but suffer from low conductivity and deteriorated mechanical properties. In this project, a naturally occurring protein (soy from soybeans) will be studied as the electrolyte matrix to replace the conventional polymers. The project will study underlying ion conduction mechanisms to understand how both excellent electrochemical and mechanical properties can be simultaneously achieved in protein-based solid electrolytes. This family of materials have not been sufficiently studied to date for the energy storage application. The outcome of this project will be fundamental knowledge of the ion-conduction mechanisms that are critical for generating new battery materials and designing next generation of energy storage devices. This project will also have broader impacts on related fields, such as all-solid-state electrochemical devices and 'green and sustainable' functional biomaterials.  

The primary goal of the this fundamental research project is to study the decoupled ion-conduction mechanism and fabrication and characterization of high-performance protein-based solid electrolytes through a combination of molecular simulations and experiments. The protein-based solid electrolytes will simultaneously have both excellent electrochemical and mechanical properties. The molecular dynamic simulations will be applied to identify and to quantify different contributions to the ion-conduction. The experimental platform from this project will enable coherent investigation from material fabrication, characterization to performance evaluation of the protein-based polymeric solid electrolytes. The simulations will provide detailed information on molecular interactions and structural reorganizations, which will guide experiments during the fabrication process. The objectives of this project include: (1) investigation of ion-conduction mechanisms through atomistic simulations; (2) study of interactions and structures of protein-ion complex under different fabrication conditions; (3) characterization and evaluation of the properties of the final solid polymeric electrolytes and establishment of structure-property relationships. The intellectual merits of this research are: deepening fundamental understanding of new ion-conduction mechanisms, initiating a new study route for fabrication of advanced solid electrolytes and extending the mechanisms to other natural and synthetic proteins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The key outcomes include 15 published journal papers, 2 manuscripts under review, filed 1 provisional patent, 2 invited talks in international conferences, gave 3 seminars off and on campuses, and 6 presented posters in national conferences and local meetings, and 1 oral presentation on campus.

Journal papers:

1)      M.Chen, C.Li, X.Fu, W.Wei, X.Fan, A.Hattori, Z.Chen, J.Liu* and W.H.Zhong*, Advanced Energy Materials, 10 (9): 1903642, 2020.

2)      X.Fu, F.Dunne, M.Chen, W.H.Zhong, Nanoscale, 12, 5483-5493, 2020.

3)      M.Chen, Z.Chen, X.Fu and W.H.Zhong, J. of Mater Chem. A, 8, 7377-7389, 2020.

4)      M.Chen, X.Fu, J.Liu, Z.Chen and W.H.Zhong, Chemsuschem, 14, 2226 – 2236, 2021.

5)      M.Chen, X.Fu, Z.Chen, J.Liu and W.H.Zhong, Advanced Functional Materials, 31, 2006744, 2021.

6)      X.Fu, R.Odstrcil, M.Qiu, J.Liu and W.H.Zhong, Energy Storage Materials, 42: 22-33, 2021.

7)      C.H.Ying, X.Fu, W.H.Zhong, J.Liu, J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 12 (2021) 9429-9435.

8)      C.Wang, C.Ying, J.Shang, S.E.Karcher, J.McCloy, J.Liu and W.H.Zhong, ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, DOI: 10.1021/acsami.2c10667, 14:43886-43896, 2022.

9)      C.Wang, X.Fu, S.Lin, J.Liu and W.H.Zhong, Journal of Energy Chemistry, 64, 485 – 495, 2022.

10)   C.Wang, X.Fu, C.Ying, J.Liu, W.Zhong, Chem. Eng. J. 437, 135283, 2022

11)   C.Wang, R.Odstrcil, J.Liu, W.-H. Zhong, J. Energy Chem. 73: 248–258, 2022

12)   X.Fu, M.J.Hurlock, C.Ding, X.Li, Q.Zhang, W.H.Zhong, Small. 18: 1–13, 2022

13)   C.H. ing, CX.Wang, W.H.Zhong and J.Liu, Advanced Materials Technologies, 8: 2201875, 2023

14)   C.Wang, P.Sireesha, J.Shang, J.McCloy, J.Liu, & W.H.Zhong, Ceramics International, 49: 32652-32662, 2023.

15)   C.Wang and W.H.Zhong, Electrochimica Acta, 441, 141860, 2023.

 

Seminar and Poster/Oral presentations: 12

 (1)  X.W.Fu and W.H.Zhong, Proteins as Multifunctional Polymers for Sustainable Energy Storage Application, 16th Pacific Polymer Conference, Singapore, December 8-12, 2019. (Session chair, invited talk)

(2)  W.H.Zhong, Applications of Natural Protein in Sustainable Energy Storage, Green Energy & Expo, Rome, Italy, October 14-16, 2019. (Keynote talk, abstract).

(3)  J.J.Liu and W.H.Zhong*, Multi-functional Air-filters Made from Abundant Natural Proteins, 16th Pacific Polymer Conference, Singapore, December 8-12, 2019. (Poster)

(4)  X.Fu, Y.Wang, X.Wang, F.Dunne and W.H.Zhong, Gum-like Nanocomposites as Interfacial Materials for Energy Storage Devices, ASME 2019 International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition, Salt Lake City, November 8-14, 2019. (Poster)

(5)  W.H.Zhong, Natural Proteins for Functional Applications: Nanocompsosites, Energy storage and Environment, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, February 14, 2020. (Seminar)

(6)  C.Wang, X.Fu, S.Lin, J.Liu and W.H.Zhong, A Protein-enabled Protective film for Stabilizing Lithium-metal Batteries, Presentation on Graduate and Professional Students Association (GPSA) Research Expo, Washington state university, March 25, 2022. (Poster)

(7)  C.Wang and W.H.Zhong, Natural Protein for Safe and Long-Cycling Lithium Metal Batteries, Three Minutes Thesis (Oral presentation for Graduate Students’ Research Competitions), Washington State University, March 9, 2022. (Oral presentation)

(8)  J.Liu, Modeling and Simulations of Protein Conformational Changes, School of MME, WSU-Tri Cities, ME598 seminar, April 08, 2022. (Seminar)

(9)  C.Wang, X.Fu, S.Li, J.Liu, & W.H.Zhong, A Protein-enabled Protective Film for Stabilizing Lithium-metal Batteries, Advanced Automotive Battery Conference, San Diego, CA, Dec 5-8, 2022. (Poster)

(10)  C.Wang, X.Fu, S.Lin, J.Liu, & W.H.Zhong, A Protein-enabled Protective Film for Stabilizing Lithium-metal Batteries, Mechanical & Materials Engineering Research Symposium, WSU, Pullman, WA, Oct 26, 2022. (Poster)

(11)  C.Wang, C.Ying, J.Shang, S.Karcher, J.McCloy., J.Liu and W.H.Zhong, A Protein-enabled Coating for Stabilizing Li Metal Batteries, International Battery Seminar & Exhibit, Orlando, FL, March 20-23, 2023. (Poster)

(12)  C. Ying, Decoupled Ion Transport Mechanism in Protein-based Solid Electrolytes through Density Functional Theory Calculations and Experiments, in School of MME, WSU, Apr 21, 2023 (Seminar)

 

Other achievements:

(3)   Teaching:

  1. Polymeric Materials, for undergraduates: Fall 2019, enrollment: 66, including 62 undergraduate students and 4 graduate students; Fall 2020, enrollment: 39, including 35 undergraduates and 4 graduate students; Fall 2021, enrollment: 29, including 27 undergraduates and 2 graduate students; Fall 2022, enrollment: 20 undergraduate students.
  2. Polymeric Nanocomposites and Functionalities, Fall 2020, enrollment: 29, including 26 graduate students and 3 undergraduate students

 

(4)    Outreach Activities:  

 * Visited Nanyang Technological University of Singapore to introduce this research project and our Materials Science and Engineering program for recruiting students, Dec 2019.

* Made a presentation at Undergraduate Research Mixer organized by Society of Women Engineers, WSU, for promoting undergraduate students’ participating in research, Feb 15, 2023.

 

(6)   Advising:

1 post-docs: Dr. Xuewei Fu,

3 PhD students: Chunhua Ying, Chenxu Wang, Ryan Odstrcil

3 undergraduate students: Steven Luck/Summer and Fall 2020; Michael T. Stuart/Fall 2021, and Sebastian N. Walker/Summer 2022;

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2023
Modified by: Weihong (Katie) Zhong
